awd_titl_txt: Integrating and ground truthing the profiling float microrosette
awd_abstract_narration:
The autonomous profiling float platform provides the potential for orders-of-magnitude improvement in ocean observing, relative to ships.  This fact has already been realized by physical oceanographers studying the ocean heat budget and large-scale mixing processes and is now gaining momentum in the ocean biogeochemistry and ecological modeling communities.   The development of new chemical sensors for measurement of CO2 dissolved in the ocean will improve our ability to quantify globally significant biogeochemical processes such as annual net community production in the ocean; and, in addition, the process of ocean acidification which is considered to be one of the most significant anthropogenic threats to the marine ecosystem. This research will develop a new technology known as the Micro-Rosette which will ultimately contribute a new tool to the short list of sensors available for integration into autonomous profiling floats.

The Micro-Rosette is a device intended to operate specifically on board a profiling float.  The system captures sub-milliliter volumes of seawater at pre-determined depths, stores the samples for a period of time, analyzes all of the discrete seawater samples ex situ (at the park depth), ejects them, and then repeats the cycle.  When combined with a typical profiling float cycle, this approach adapts to the float's ascent/decent/park cycle, taking advantage of the multi-day park cycle to perform all of the chemical analyses.  Determination of dissolved inorganic carbon is accomplished through acidification of the seawater sample, equilibration across a gas-permeable membrane, and quantification via a conductivity measurement.  The Micro Rosette is purposefully built for profiling floats, and by taking advantage of the extended park cycle to carry out chemical analyses, this approach embraces the fact that many chemical analysis techniques require a time-dependent reaction or diffusion step leading to response times that make such analyses poorly suited for on-the-fly measurements. The application of this research is the measurement of total dissolved inorganic carbon, but the concept of a micro-rosette system is well-suited to several other types of analyses such as ammonia, organic carbon, and iron, and may potentially lead to a new family of profiling-float-ready wet chemical analyzers.

inst.inst_name: University of California-San Diego Scripps Inst of Oceanography

por.por_cntn:
We developed and shore tested an integrated autonomous sampling and analysis platform called the “Micro-Rosette”.  The purpose of this work was to address the limitations of sensors on moving platforms due to response time.  Response time of wet chemical analyzers excludes autonomous sensing of many properties of interest from mobile platforms.  The Micro-Rosette concept uses a microfluidic sampling and storage manifold to autonomously capture sub-milliliter volumes of seawater at pre-determined depths, store the samples for a period of time, sequentially analyze all of the discrete seawater samples, eject spent samples, and then repeat the cycle.  The major successes of this work include: 1) development of a new low power controller, capable of operating up to three stepper driven pumps, 50+ micro solenoid valves, a microfluidic capacitive conductivity detector, and various peripheral serial devices; 2) a complex 3D printed multiplexed flow manifold designed to operate (with pumps and valves) in an oil-filled housing, allowing for the entire system to function at depth; and 3) achievement of high precision  measurement (~0.1% RSD) of dissolved inorganic carbon in a benchtop setting.  With the completion of this project, the prototype Micro-Rosette has been tested in situ in a seawater test tank with promising results.

 


Last Modified: 12/30/2021
Modified by: Todd Martz

We developed and shore tested an integrated autonomous sampling and analysis platform called the "Micro-Rosette".  The purpose of this work was to address the limitations of sensors on moving platforms due to response time.  Response time of wet chemical analyzers excludes autonomous sensing of many properties of interest from mobile platforms.
